data.text: Which Shoes and Pedals for Cycle Touring
Recommendations for shoes and pedals, please.
I love my 510 Kestrels matched to my Shimano M-324 SPD pedals.
data.author: Mike Schmitt

data.text: What‚Äôs your preference? Flats or clips?
data.author: Dave Carvajal

data.text: I strongly suggest going to a bike/accessory shop for this, and trying on a ton of shoes. Different brands and shoe models fit differently and no foot is the same as another. About the only specific suggestion I would make for a first pair is that it be a two bolt pattern (particularly Shimano SPD, as they're inexpensive, durable, the shoes are easy to walk in, and it's what you'll find on most gym spin bikes if you've ever considered doing that).
data.author: Braden Graham

data.text: Crank brothers for pedals

data.text: SPD's & sandals !
data.author: Patrick Lorenze

data.text: Everyone's feet are different. Go try on some shoes and see what's comfortable. Then find a compatible set of pedals. I like my crank bros double shot 2 pedals, they have clips on one side and flats on the other, but they don't have the best grip on the flat side, so if you do extreme terrain they're not ideal.

data.text: For pedals I have two sets for my two sets of wheels‚Ä¶ I use SPD-SLs when I‚Äôm running road wheels and then I‚Äôve got some crank bros candy pedals for when I‚Äôm running gravel wheels. As far as shoes, your LBS might have a program where you can buy a pair and if it doesn‚Äôt work you can take them back for a credit towards a different pair. Mine does.
